anchor.surface_text: Section 14 runs as follows 14.  1  The Special Judge shall, by an order in writing, fix a date for enquiring into the claims made in pursuance of the numberice published in accordance with s. 9 and give numberice of such date to all the claimants and the person who made the application under s. 4. The Special Judge shall examine each claim and after hearing such parties as desired to be heard and companysidering the evidence, if any, produced by them shall determine the amount, if any, due from the landlord to the claimant on the date of the application under s. 4.

issues.text: question of interpretation of s. 15 of the United Provinces Encumbered Estates Act, 1934

anchor.surface_text: This appeal raises the question of interpretation of s. 15 of the United Provinces Encumbered Estates Act, 1934. On March 1, 1924, Sardar Nihal Singh, the predecessor of the appellant before us, borrowed a sum of rupees one lakh from Raja Durga Narain Singh, predecessor

issues.text: The real controversy in the case between the parties is, as already indicated, as regards the interpretation of s. 15 of the Encumbered Estates Act

anchor.surface_text: The real controversy in the case between the parties is, as already indicated, as regards the interpretation of s. 15 of the Encumbered Estates Act. The relevant portion of s. 15 is in these words-

issues.text: whether the judgment of the Chief Court was one of affirmance under Art. 133 (1) of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: the Constitutional point which he had wanted to raise was whether the judgment of the Chief Court was one of affirmance under Art. 133 1  of the Constitution

issues.text: whether when in ascertaining the amount due on the basis of a loan, at the date of the suit, the Court which passed the decree did not allow interest exceeding the portion of the principal which was still due at the date of the suit, the finding as regards the amount due is inconsistent with s. 14(4)(a) because the consequence of that finding as regards the amount due, together with interest allowed thereupon, is that on the date of the application the amount of interest due exceeds the portion of the principal remaining unpaid on the date of the application

whether in so far as the preliminary decree allowed interest pendente lite on the above amount from March 19, 1932, to March 29, 1935, at 8 per cent per annum, it was inconsistent with sub-s. (7) of s. 14

anchor.surface_text: It held however that in so far as this decree allowed interest pendente lite on the above amount from March 19, 1932, to March 29, 1935, at 8 per annum, it was inconsistent with sub-s. 7 of s. 14. The Chief Court accordingly held that this interest pendente lite must be reduced to 4 1/4 simple.

anchor.surface_text: Thus, if for example, the provisions of the Usurious Loans Act. 1918, would be beneficial to the applicant landlord and have not been taken into consideration

holdings.text: The Special Judge is even where there has been a decree by a civil court in respect of a loan bound to follow the provisions of s. 14(4)(a) of the Act so that the amount of interest which he can hold to be due on the date of the application must not exceed the portion of the principal found to be due on the date of the application.

anchor.surface_text: Our conclusion therefore is that the Special Judge is even where there has been a decree by a civil court in respect of a loan bound to follow the provisions of s. 14 4  a  of the Act so that the amount of interest

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.15 requires accepting prior findings only if consistent with s.14; prior decree findings rejected if their consequence violates s.14(4)(a) limit on application date; deliberate legislative choice to benefit landlord by capping interest at principal on that date.

holdings.text: When ascertaining amount due at suit date without exceeding principal then, but consequence with pendente lite interest leads to interest exceeding principal on application date, the finding is inconsistent with s.14(4)(a).
holdings.reasoning_summary: Cannot ignore 'on the date of the application'; contention that suit date suffices rejected as it defeats purpose and misreads s.15; must check effect of findings on application date.

holdings.text: The Special Judge should have held the amount of interest due on the date of the application, i.e., October 26, 1936, to amount to rupees one lakh only, that being the principal which was still due on that date.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly in the present case the Special Judge should have held the amount of interest due oil the date of the application, i.e., October 26, 1936, to amount to rupees one lakh only, that being the princip

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of s.14(4)(a) to facts: principal Rs.1 lakh, interest capped there.

holdings.text: The proper decree the Special Judge should have passed therefore was one for rupees two lakhs for the loan with permissible interest, plus Rs. 4,314-2-9, Rs. 51-3-0 and rupee one on account of costs, that is, for a total sum of Rs. 2,04,366-5-9 with proportionate costs with interest pendente lite and future interest at the rate of 4 per cent per annum simple from the date of the application, i.e., October 26, 1936, till realisation.

anchor.surface_text: The proper decree the Special Judge should have passed therefore was one for rupees two lakhs for the loan with permissible interest, plus Rs. 4,314-2-9, Rs. 51-3-0 and rupee one on account of costs, that is,

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.14(7) mandates simple money decree for amount due + costs + pendente lite/future interest <= s.27 rate (4%); accepts prior costs findings as consistent.

holdings.text: Accordingly, we allow the appeal, set aside the decree passed by the courts below and order that in place of the decree made by the Trial Court be substituted a money decree in the terms as mentioned above.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Lower courts erred in interpreting s.15/s.14; substitute correct decree per law.

holdings.text: The view in Pandit Ramsagar Prasad v. Mst. Shayama which has been followed by the Chief Court in the present case is wrong.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Treats suit date as application date, defeating s.14(4)(a) purpose; not natural reading of s.15.

holdings.text: A finding in a decree made by a civil court that the creditor is entitled to interest only at the rates specified in U.P. Agriculturists Relief Act was inconsistent with s.14(4)(c) and not binding on the Special Judge; there can be no doubt about the correctness of this view.
holdings.reasoning_summary: s.14(4)(c) explicitly excludes Agriculturists Relief Act; prior findings based thereon inconsistent per s.15.

holdings.text: Provisions like the Usurious Loans Act, 1918, beneficial to landlord must be applied by Special Judge if not considered in prior decree, modifying findings inconsistent with s.14(4)(b).

anchor.surface_text: Thus, if for example, the provisions of the Usurious Loans Act. 1918, would be beneficial to the applicant landlord and have not been taken into consideration

holdings.reasoning_summary: Illustrative example of inconsistency under s.14(4)(b); Special Judge exercises civil court powers subject to s.14 limits.

Lachhmi Narain 2 to companysider the question whether a finding in a decree made by a civil companyrt that the creditor is entitled to interest only at the rates specified in U. P. Agriculturists Relief Act was inconsistent with the

precedents.case_name: Pandit Ramsagar Prasad v. Mst. Shayama
precedents.cited_proposition: The view that the decree finding is not inconsistent with s.14(4)(a) of the U.P. Encumbered Estates Act if interest did not exceed principal at the date of the suit, even if it does at the date of the application under s.4

anchor.surface_text: Rukun-uddin v. Lachhmi Narain 2 to companysider the question whether a finding in a decree made by a civil companyrt that the creditor is entitled to interest only at the rates specified in U. P. Agriculturists Relief Act was inconsistent with the A.I.R. 1939 Oudh 75. I.L.R. 1945 All. 307. provisions of s. 14 of the U. P. Encumbered Estates Act and was therefore number binding on the Special Judge hearing an application under the U. P. Encumbered. Estates Act.

precedents.cited_proposition: A finding in a decree made by a civil court that the creditor is entitled to interest only at the rates specified in U. P. Agriculturists Relief Act, 1934 is inconsistent with s.14(4)(c) of the U.P. Encumbered Estates Act and therefore not binding on the Special Judge
precedents.cited_holding: Such a finding must be held to be inconsistent with the provisions of s. 14 and could therefore not be binding on the Special Judge

anchor.surface_text: the view taken in Ramsagar Prasads Case 1 . For the reasons mentioned earlier how- ever we are of opinion that the view in Ramsagar Prasads Case 1 which has been followed by the Chief Court in the present case is wrong.

precedents.cited_proposition: The interpretation of s.15 of the U.P. Encumbered Estates Act in relation to s.14(4)(a) regarding inconsistency of decree findings

Our companyclusion therefore is that the Special Judge is even where there has been a decree by a civil companyrt in respect of a loan bound to follow the provisions of s. 14 4 a of the Act so that the amount of interest which he can hold to be due on the date of the application must number exceed the portion of the principal found to be due on the date of the application.
